title: City Travel Rewards
problem_statement:
City Travel Rewards

Problem Description

Jack lives in a city that has A tourist places and M roads connecting them. All the roads in the city are one-way (i.e., directed roads). As a result, some tourist places may become isolated and abandoned. Two tourist places may have multiple direct roads connecting them.

The city authorities have decided to launch a loyalty program to attract tourists. In this loyalty program, a person will receive rewards when traveling through roads. Each road has a fixed base reward point. When a person travels through a road for the i-th time, with a base reward point of Z, they will receive a reward calculated using the formula B + (i-1)^2 * Z. If the reward comes out to be negative according to this formula, the reward will be set to zero.

Jack wants to know the maximum reward points he can accumulate using this loyalty program. Since Jack is busy, he asks you to find it for him.

You are given integers A and B, where A represents the number of tourist places, and B represents Jack's starting place. You also have a 2D array C of size M by 3, where C[i][0] and C[i][1] respectively represent the starting and ending tourist places of the i-th one-way road, and C[i][2] represents the base reward point of the i-th road.

Note:
There may be roads that lead from a tourist place back to itself.

Input Format

First argument contains an integer A.
Second argument contains an integer B.
Third argument contains a 2D integer array C.

Output Format

Return an integer denoting the required answer.

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
A = 3
B = 1
C = [[1, 2, 1], [2, 3, 4], [3, 1, 0]]
Output:
9

Explanation:
For Input 1:
Jack travels from tourist place 1 to tourist place 2 and gets 1 reward point.
He then travels from tourist place 2 to tourist place 3 and gets 4 reward points.
He repeats the same routes for the second and third time, earning rewards as follows:
Tourist place 1 to tourist place 2: 0 reward points (2nd time), 0 reward points (3rd time).
Tourist place 2 to tourist place 3: 5 reward points (2nd time), 8 reward points (3rd time).
Tourist place 3 to tourist place 1: 1 reward points (2nd time), 4 reward points (3rd time).
Tourist place 3 to tourist place 3: 0 reward points (2nd time), 0 reward points (3rd time).
The total reward points Jack accumulates are (1 + 0 + 0) + (4 + 5 + 8) + (0 + 1 + 4) = 9.

Example 2:

Input:
A = 1
B = 1
C = [[1, 2, 1], [2, 3, 4]]
Output:
5

Explanation:
For Input 2:
Jack travels from tourist place 1 to tourist place 2 and receives 1 reward points.
He then travels from tourist place 2 to tourist place 3 and earns 4 reward points.
As there are no further connections from tourist place 3, Jack cannot continue his journey to other tourist places.
Therefore, the total reward points that Jack accumulates are (1 + 4) = 5.

Constraints

  • 1 <= A <= 10^5
  • 0 <= M <= 10^5
  • 1 <= B <= A
  • 1 <= C[i][0], C[i][1] <= A
  • 0 <= C[i][2] <= 10^5
